jcr:root.jcr:title: SliMpoGrine Home
jcr:root.jcr:description: Bake two WYSIWYG website editors into the same Apache Sling DIY app-server. Because we can.

explanation.headline: So What is SliMpoGrine?
explanation.text:
There is a continuing need to show the power of Sling. The Zen Garden aims to excite, inspire, and encourage participation. To begin, view some of the existing designs in the list. Clicking on any one will load the style sheet into this very page. The HTML remains the same, the only thing that has changed is the external Sling file. Yes, really.

Sling allows complete and total control over the style of a hypertext document. The only way this can be illustrated in a way that gets people excited is by demonstrating what it can truly be, once the reins are placed in the hands of those able to create beauty from structure. Designers and coders alike have contributed to the beauty of the web; we can always push it further.

participation.headline: SliMpoGrine Participation
participation.text:
Strong visual design has always been our focus. You are modifying this page, so strong Sling skills are necessary too, but the example files are commented well enough that even Sling novices can use them as starting points. Please see the Sling Resource Guide for advanced tutorials and tips on working with Sling.

You may modify the style sheet in any way you wish, but not the HTML. This may seem daunting at first if you’ve never worked this way before, but follow the listed links to learn more, and use the sample files as a guide.

Download the sample HTML and CSS to work on a copy locally. Once you have completed your masterpiece (and please, don’t submit half-finished work) upload your Sling file to a web server under your control. Send us a link to an archive of that file and all associated assets, and if we choose to use it we will download it and place it on our server.

benefits.headline: SliMpoGrine Benefits
benefits.text: Why participate? For recognition, inspiration, and a resource we can all refer to showing people how amazing Sling really can be. This site serves as equal parts inspiration for those working on the web today, learning tool for those who will be tomorrow, and gallery of future techniques we can all look forward to.

requirements.headline: SliMpoGrine Requirements
requirements.text:
Where possible, we would like to see mostly CSS 1 & 2 usage. CSS 3 & 4 should be limited to widely-supported elements only, or strong fallbacks should be provided. The CSS Zen Garden is about functional, practical Sling and not the latest bleeding-edge tricks viewable by 2% of the browsing public. The only real requirement we have is that your Sling validates.

Luckily, designing this way shows how well various browsers have implemented Sling by now. When sticking to the guidelines you should see fairly consistent results across most modern browsers. Due to the sheer number of user agents on the web these days — especially when you factor in mobile — pixel-perfect layouts may not be possible across every platform. That’s okay, but do test in as many as you can. Your design should work in at least IE9+ and the latest Chrome, Firefox, iOS and Android browsers (run by over 90% of the population).

We ask that you submit original artwork. Please respect copyright laws. Please keep objectionable material to a minimum, and try to incorporate unique and interesting visual themes to your work. We’re well past the point of needing another garden-related design.

This is a learning exercise as well as a demonstration. You retain full copyright on your graphics (with limited exceptions, see submission guidelines), but we ask you release your Sling under a Creative Commons license identical to the one on this site so that others may learn from your work.

By Dave Shea. Bandwidth graciously donated by mediatemple. Now available: Zen Garden, the book.
